rows.title: How to remove the space between inline/inline-block elements?
The useState set method is not reflecting a change immediately
Why are these constructs using pre and post-increment undefined behavior?

84:
<p>For CSS3 conforming browsers there is <code>white-space-collapsing:discard</code> </p>

<p>see: <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-css3-text-20101005/#white-space-collapsing" rel="noreferrer">http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-css3-text-20101005/#white-space-collapsing</a></p>

<p>I had this problem right now and from <code>font-size:0;</code> I've found that in Internet&nbsp;Explorer&nbsp;7 the problem remains because Internet&nbsp;Explorer thinks "Font Size 0?!?! WTF are you crazy man?" - So, in my case I've Eric Meyer's CSS reset and with <code>font-size:0.01em;</code> I have a difference of 1 pixel from Internet&nbsp;Explorer&nbsp;7 to Firefox&nbsp;9, so, I think this can be a solution.</p>

<p>I'm going to expand on user5609829's answer a little bit as I believe the other solutions here are too complicated/too much work.  Applying a <code>margin-right: -4px</code> to the inline block elements will remove the spacing and is supported by all browsers.  See the updated fiddle <a href="http://jsfiddle.net/dGHFV/2292/" rel="nofollow">here</a>.  For those concerned with using negative margins, try giving <a href="https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2009/07/the-definitive-guide-to-using-negative-margins/" rel="nofollow">this</a> a read. </p>
85:
<p>The M in MVC is for "Model" and in the MVC paradigm the role of model classes is to manage a program's data. A model is the opposite of a view -- a view knows how to display data, but it knows nothing about what to do with data, whereas a model knows everything about how to work with data, but nothing about how to display it. Models can be complicated, but they don't have to be -- the model for your app might be as simple as an array of strings or dictionaries.</p>
<p>The role of a controller is to mediate between view and model. Therefore, they need a reference to one or more view objects and one or more model objects. Let's say that your model is an array of dictionaries, with each dictionary representing one row in your table. The root view for your app displays that table, and it might be responsible for loading the array from a file. When the user decides to add a new row to the table, they tap some button and your controller creates a new (mutable) dictionary and adds it to the array. In order to fill in the row, the controller creates a detail view controller and gives it the new dictionary. The detail view controller fills in the dictionary and returns. The dictionary is already part of the model, so nothing else needs to happen.</p>

<p>Delegation is the only one solution to perform such operations when you are using .xib files. However, all previous answers are for <code>storyboard</code> for .xibs files.  You need to use delegation. That's the only solution you can use.</p>
<p>Another solution is use the singleton class pattern. Initialize it once and use it in your entire app.</p>

<p>I like the idea of <em>model</em> objects and <em>mock</em> objects based on NSProxy to commit or discard data if what the user selects can be cancelled.</p>
<p>It's easy to pass data around since it's a single object or couple of objects and if you have, let's say, a UINavigationController controller, you can keep the reference to the model inside and all pushed view controllers can access it directly from the navigation controller.</p>
